appendix.title: The Afghanistan Mission Network (AMN) Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards

sect1.title: General
sect1.para: NATO, through its interoperability directive, has recognized that widespread interoperability is a key component in achieving effective and efficient operations. In many of the operations world-wide in which the military of the NATO nations are engaged, they participate together with a wide variety of the military of other nations and non-military organizations on the ground. The NATO Interoperability Standards and Profile (NISP) provides the necessary guidance and technical components to support project implementations and transition to NATO Network Enabled Capability (NNEC).

sect2.title: Authorised Version
sect2.para: The standards extant for the AMN are described in the NISP. This is published as ADatP-34 by the NATO C3 Board. As part of the NISP, an AMN Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards has been published among the several operational profiles permitted as part of ADatP-34. The latest authorised version can be found in Volume 4 of the NISP [ADaTP-34(G)-REV1, Volume 4 Annex D, 8 March 2013]. These are the extant and NATO agreed list of practical standards to achieve immediately usable interoperability between the national network extensions of the NATO nations, coalition partners and NATO provided capabilities.
Nations participating in the AMN have agreed to comply with the AMN joining instructions, of which these standards form an integral part.

sect2.title: Application
sect2.para: The AMN Profile will be used in the implementation of NATO Common Funded Systems. Nations participating in AMN agree to use this profile at Network Interconnection Points (NIPs) and at other Service Interoperability Points as applicable.

NNEC Services must be able to function in a network environment containing firewalls and various routing and filtering schemes; therefore, developers must use standard and well-known ports wherever possible, and document non-standard ports as part of their service interface. Service developers must assume network behaviour and performance consistent with the existing limits of these networks, taking bandwidth limitations and potentially unreliable networks into account.

sect2.title: Life-Cycle of Standards
sect2.para:
ADatP-34 defines four stages within the life-cycle of a standard: emerging, mandatory, fading and retired
The FMN Profile has been further refined and also additionally uses 4 obligation categories of Mandatory, Conditional, Recommended and Optional to assist with conformity assessments. Where relevant these have also been used in an AMN context.. In those situations where multiple stages are mentioned, the AMN Profile recommends dates by which the transition to the next stage is to be completed by all AMN members. If a TCN (or NCI Agency) decides to implement emerging standards it is her responsibility to maintain backwards compatibility to the mandatory standard.

sect3.title: Indicating Changes to the AMN Profile
sect3.para: Volume 4 of the Joining, Membership and Exit Instructions (JMEI) is oriented around the AMN Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards. The AMN Profile is maintained within this document.

The extant authorised version of the AMN Profile is as published in ADaTP-34(G). This formal published version of the AMN Profile is to only be originated from this document (i.e. Vol 4 of the JMEI published as NCI Agency Technical Report TR-2013/ACO008868/04).

The NCI Agency acts as the custodian for the AMN Profile and is to be used as the conduit for changes (via her membership of the AMN AWG). This must be via the process outlined at section 2.7 of the JMEI Volume 4

Any changes already collectively agreed by the AMN TCN and NCI Agency via the AMN AWG for use on the AMN but not yet published in ADaTP-34 were indicated as changes in the document. These changes will be submitted for publication in the next authorised issue of ADatP-34 (i.e. ADaTP-34(H) and thereafter).

sect2.title: Relationship to NATO C3 Classification Taxonomy
sect2.para: The AMN has been designed and is managed as far as possible using a service approach. The AMN Services are based on the NATO C3 Classification Taxonomy AC/322-N(2012)0092-AS1.

The C3 Classification Taxonomy is used to identify particular services and associated Service Interoperability Point where two entities will interface and the standards in use by the relevant systems.
Where required, the implementation of the standard is described in an annex associated with the Service.

Where a composite suite of services (with their standards) are required to implement a suite of services that are typically grouped together to form a familiar “composite service” or a “user facing Service”, then the implementation annex is housed at the assessed “centre of gravity” of the composite service. This is done simply to keep the instructions together. This applies for those services which network engineers, system administrators, users or operators recognise as distinct (e.g. “Text based Chat”, “VoSIP” or “VTC”), and for which technical skills/specialisms/instructions already exist. For Example the VTC implementation annex is placed under “Core Enterprise Services/ Enterprise Support Services” despite the fact that the VTC “composite service” is also implemented by services in Communications Access Services, Service Management and Control etc..
The C3 Classification Taxonomy is used to structure this document, commencing with Communications and working up the Taxonomy.

sect2.title: Relationship to the Future (Federated) Mission Network
sect2.para: Subsequent NATO led missions will benefit from the modular nature of the AMN Profile, which will allow for maximum reuse of established capabilities, while accommodating unique requirements and technology improvements.

Based on the AMN Profile, a Federated Mission Network Profile of NATO Interoperability Standards has been proposed and is anticipated to be published in the next version of ADaTP-34. This will support the implementation of the Future Mission Network (FMN) Concept [MCM-0125-2012].

Given the strong linkage between AMN and FMN, the opportunity to maintain a single Federated Mission Network Profile is possible in future versions of this document, but will firstly require the establishment of the FMN Governance and FMN Framework Management Structures. To this end it is anticipated that any future development of capabilities for the AMN in the future should be done in the direction indicated by the Federated Mission Network Profile.

This AMN Profile contains footnotes from the FMN Profile that if applied would implement the AMN in the direction of the FMN. These are indicated as a footnote to the referenced standard. Please note however: The FMN notes are only included for information. They are not yet approved by the AWG for use on the AMN.

sect1.title: Communication Services
sect1.para: Definition: Communications Services interconnect systems and mechanisms for the opaque transfer of selected data between or among access points, in accordance with agreed quality parameters and without change in the form or content of the data as sent and received.
Communications Services can be further defined as:

listitem.para: Transmission Services
Transport Services
Communications Access Services

sect2.title: Transmission Services
sect2.para: Definition: Transmission Services cover the physical layer (also referred to as media layer or air-interface in wireless/satellite (SATCOM) communications) supporting Transport Services, as well as Communications Access Services. Support for the latter is relevant to personal communications systems, in which the User Appliances directly connect to the transmission element without any transport elements in between.

sect3.title: Standards
sect3.para: Although the implementation scope of AMN technically does not cover Transmission Services, there is one area that provides the foundation for the provision of federated services on the AMN. The Standards listed in table need to be adhered to.

sect2.title: Transport Services
sect2.para: Definition: Transport Services provide resource-facing services, providing metro and wide-area connectivity to the Communications Access Services that operate at the edges of the network. In that role, Transport Services interact with the Transmission Services using them as the physical layer fabric supporting the transfer of data over a variety of transmission bearers as and where needed.
Transport Services are further defined in the C3 Taxonomy, however the area that is most relevant to the AMN are:

listitem.para: Edge Transport Services

sect2.para: Definition: Edge Transport Services provide the delivery or exchange of traffic flows over different Transmission Services. The traffic flows are formatted and delivered by the Communications Access Services at the edges of the network. This "edge" in Edge Transport is the Wide Area Network (WAN) edge (i.e. the provider edge). In Protected Core Networking (PCN) terms, the edge can be considered as the entry point into the Protected Core.

sect3.title: Standards
sect3.para: The AMN is a converged IP network applying open standards and industry best practices. The AMN architecture uses interconnection based on IPv4 between the Mission Networks (also referred to as autonomous systems).

The AMN was originally conceived with IPv6 as the target for interconnecting autonomous systems (although no TCN has yet indicated that they wish to implement this on the AMN). As IPv6 is also the direction that the FMN is progressing, and as the AMN will become one the first FMN instances, IPv6 standards are now listed in the AMN Profile.

It is now advised that all new equipment, services and applications must support a dual IPv4/IPv6 stack implementation to future-proof the AMN for the long term and to enable AMN to remain in line with the development of the FMN.

The interconnection between Mission Networks is based on STANAG 5067 enhanced with a non-tactical connector and optional 1Gb/s Ethernet. STANAG 5067 provides additional implementation, security and management guidance. Due to the classification level of the AMN, dedicated transmission security (crypto) equipment is used.

entry.para: To aid rapid post event reconstruction, ALL networked equipment will be set to process time as Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). i.e. ZULU Time Zone should apply to the whole Mission Network [AMN TPT CES Sept 2011].
All new capabilities shall use NTPv4. Some legacy systems may still need to use NTPv3.

TCN connecting to the AMN Core must use the time service of the AMN Core
For an FMN implementation, if TCN also provide an equivalent to the AMN Core (known in FMN terms as “Option A”), then the time service could also be provided over a network path to a stratum-1 time server on the TCN (Option A) network..

A stratum-1 time server is directly linked (not over a network path) to a reliable source of UTC time (Universal Time Coordinate) such as GPS, WWV, or CDMA transmissions through a modem connection, satellite, or radio.
Stratum-1 devices must implement IPv4 and IPv6 so that they can be used as timeservers for IPv4 and IPv6 Mission Network Elements

sect3.title: Unified Communication and Collaboration Services
sect3.para: Definition: Unified Communication and Collaboration Services provide users with a range of interoperable collaboration capabilities, based on standards that fulfill operational requirements. They will enable real-time situational updates to time-critical planning activities between coalition partners, communities of interest (e.g. the Intel community or the Logistics community), and other agencies. Levels of collaboration include awareness, shared information, coordination and joint product development.

Different use cases require different levels of protection of these communication and collaboration services. For voice or audio-based collaboration services, the AMN profile can provide interoperability standards for two different scenarios
FMN: Under the FMN profile, 3 scenarios are offered. The first being pure Voice over IP (VoIP) network services, i.e. conventional IP telephony. The choice of this over VoSIP being purely based on classification of the network.:

listitem.para: A. Voice over Secure IP (VoSIP) network services
B. Network agnostic Secure Voice Services (such as 3G, IP/4G, ISDN)

sect3.para:
On AMN, VoSIP is mandatory. If however network agnostic Secure Voice services are required in addition to VoSIP
The only scenario where this would apply would be in the case that crypto devices cannot be supplied, protected and managed on site and physical access to the AMN is hence not available at that location., then Secure Communications Interoperability Protocol (SCIP) specifications as defined for audio-based collaboration services (end-to-end protected voice) over any network should be used
If SCIP is used, then access to the AMN can only be possible if a gateway for SCIP multi-conferencing and interconnection to VoSIP networks is provided. AMN. Additionally to achieve this there would need to be agreement to re-use a Key Management system that is already deployed in ISAF (for example that used for the OMLTs).. As an addition to SLP Profiles the following proficiency description could also be considered
Source: International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) Holistic Descriptors of operational language proficiency (adapted):
For effective voice communications, a proficient speakers shall:
1. communicate effectively in voice-only (telephone/radio) and in face-to-face situations;
2. communicate on common, concrete and work-related topics with accuracy and clarity;
3. use appropriate communicative strategies to exchange messages and to recognize and resolve misunderstandings (e.g. to check, confirm, or clarify information) in a general or work-related context;

4. handle successfully and with relative ease the linguistic challenges presented by a complication or unexpected turn of events that occurs within the context of a routine mission situation or communicative task with which they are otherwise familiar; and
5. use a dialect or accent which is intelligible to the multinational mission community.

sect1.title: Service Management and Control
sect1.para: Definition: Service Management and Control (SMC) provides a collection of capabilities to coherently manage components in a federated service-enabled information technology infrastructure. SMC tools enable service providers to provide the desired quality of service as specified by the customer. In a federated environment such as the AMN, utilizing common process and data is a critical enabler to management of the network.
